wiki.summary: “Kills You Slowly” is the second single of the year for The Chainsmokers, who are continuing their release schedule established last year, with Sick Boy. “Kills You Slowly” follows up the massive collaboration with 5 Seconds of Summer, “Who Do You Love,” and talks about a couple that is fighting and on edge, trying to salvage what’s left of a seemingly broken relationship. Both sides put on fake personas to do so, and try to hold in arguments, fights, and disagreements to please others, even if it does kill them slowly. Read more on Last.fm.
wiki.content: “Kills You Slowly” is the second single of the year for The Chainsmokers, who are continuing their release schedule established last year, with Sick Boy. “Kills You Slowly” follows up the massive collaboration with 5 Seconds of Summer, “Who Do You Love,” and talks about a couple that is fighting and on edge, trying to salvage what’s left of a seemingly broken relationship. Both sides put on fake personas to do so, and try to hold in arguments, fights, and disagreements to please others, even if it does kill them slowly. The song features a classic Chainsmokers guitar riff in the background but also has a down-beat trap influence with London on Da Track doing Misc. Production on the track. The song was initially teased on March 21, 2019, when The Chainsmokers shared a video on their Instagram account featuring a recap of their tour in Australia and South Africa. At the end of the video, a snippet of the song is played. The release date was eventually revealed through an Instagram comment by The Chainsmokers. "haha yes this is drew singing, and yes he takes a ton of lessons so his voice is changing and what he is capable of… the song is a real vibe but make sure you listen to the lyrics also :)" — Alex via Reddit Mysteriously, the artwork for “Kills You Slowly” changed after its release from a burning car to an empty field. It is unknown as to why. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.
